Honor Commission: Indefensible Oversight
After six months of diligent, un-publicized, secret
work, the Honor. Coinmission has altered its Constitution
to provide a more judicious trial procedure and give the
accused "every benefit possible."
•

The amendments are appropriate, as far as they go.
However, we who sit on the outside looking in would
offer an additional amendment. Our amendment would
transfigure Article X, which now allows amendment of
the Honor Commission Constitution merely by a 3 4
vote of the Commission and "subsequent approval of the
Student Council."
We would propose that the amendments be presented
to the undergraduate body to affirm or reject as they gee
tit. It is the undergraduate who will be affected by any
alteration of the System. It is the undergraduate who
should have the final voice in the matter.
Apparently the Commission now submits amendments to the Student Council in order to give the student,
acting through his elected representatives, the chance to
ratify the amendments.
Why not eliminate the middle man and go directly
to the students? In the past the undergraduates haven't
used the Council as a vehicle to express their views. It
is not to be expected that they will do so in this case.
This is not to insinuate that they have no interest, or that
they would not express their opinion at the polls. Indeed,
they have every right to do so—by popular referendum.

According to the Johns Hopkins Handbook, the Honor
System is the "self-imposed moral code of a community
of gentlemen." This System, it is further explained,
•controls conduct in class and examination rooms among
other things. Lacking a referendum, the System can not
be "self-imposed."
The Honor Commission is the mere vehicle which
guides observance of Honor. Its Constitution is merely
the formalized path which'the vehicle must travel in order
to preserve and guide Honor. The people in the driver's
seat must be the undergraduates, who must be able to
express their faith in Honor.

IFB Politics
The Inter-Fraternity Board and Zeta Beta' Tau
fraternity finally gave up this week their obstructionist
tactics and compromised on the admission of the fraternity to the Board. Politics and selfishness finally gave
way to limited common sense, extremism to apparent
rationalism.
The IFS had denied ZBT admission on the grounds
the fraternity had violated the letter and undefined spirit
of the IFB Rush Rules and should not be admitted until
it complied. It did not matter that ZBT was not legally
bound by the rules and that'it did comply to some limited
extent, nor that the IFB fraternities were not obliged to
follow the rules in rushing against ZBT but could an(l,
it is alleged, did retaliate by "dirty" rushing against ZBT.
They supplemented the retaliation by denial of admission.
ZBT had demanded immediate admission or assurance of admission at a pre-set time. It saw itself as
wronged when these demands were denied, and resorted
to obstructionism.
Only when three fraternities abstained from voting
on a compromise could action be taken. Politics and
selfishness are none the less vicious, however, because
they are hidden behind the screen of abstaints.
It is hypothetical to argue that ZBT will be excluded
because the IFB will insist on the fraternity's perfection
in following rush rules. Seven of thirteen fraternilies
must agree that ZBT's major violation—an undefined
term whose meaning is at the discretion of an investigating committee and IFB which are presumed to be above
politics—is gross enough to exclude the fraternity and
prolong the quarrel. Exclusion by a 7-6 vote is improbable,
lld SO is ZBT's committing violations.
Yet because both are possible, the Board and ZBT
must keep compromise paramount to politics, selfishness
and extremism. The past makes this hope sees! difficult
of fulfillment.

"Dear Son,(Dad wrote)
"I suppose you are finding college very big and bewildering,

if you will follow a few simple rules.
"First of all, if you have any problems, take them to your
teachers. They want to help you. That's what they are there for.
Perhaps they seem a little aloof, but that is only because they
are so busy. You will find your teachers warm as toast and
friendly as pups if you will call on them at an hour when they
are not overly busy. Four a.m., for instance.
"Second,learn to budget your time. What with classes, activities, studying, and social life all competing for your time, it is
easy to fall into sloppy habits. Set up a rigid schedule and stick
to it. Remember, there are only 24 hours a day. Three of these
hours must be spent in class. For every hour in class you must,
of course, spend two hours studying. So there go six more
hours. Then, as we all know,for every hour studying, you must
Spend two hours sleeping. This accounts for twelve more hours.
Then there are meals—three hours each for breakfast and lunch,
four hours for dinner. Never forget, Sonnenberg, you must
chew each mouthful twelve hundred times. You show me a
backward student, and I'll show you a man who bolts his food.

Honor Commission: Indefensible Oversight
After six months of diligent, un-publicized, secret
work, the Honor. Coinmission has altered its Constitution
to provide a more judicious trial procedure and give the
accused "every benefit possible."
•

The amendments are appropriate, as far as they go.
However, we who sit on the outside looking in would
offer an additional amendment. Our amendment would
transfigure Article X, which now allows amendment of
the Honor Commission Constitution merely by a 3 4
vote of the Commission and "subsequent approval of the
Student Council."
We would propose that the amendments be presented
to the undergraduate body to affirm or reject as they gee
tit. It is the undergraduate who will be affected by any
alteration of the System. It is the undergraduate who
should have the final voice in the matter.
Apparently the Commission now submits amendments to the Student Council in order to give the student,
acting through his elected representatives, the chance to
ratify the amendments.
Why not eliminate the middle man and go directly
to the students? In the past the undergraduates haven't
used the Council as a vehicle to express their views. It
is not to be expected that they will do so in this case.
This is not to insinuate that they have no interest, or that
they would not express their opinion at the polls. Indeed,
they have every right to do so—by popular referendum.

According to the Johns Hopkins Handbook, the Honor
System is the "self-imposed moral code of a community
of gentlemen." This System, it is further explained,
•controls conduct in class and examination rooms among
other things. Lacking a referendum, the System can not
be "self-imposed."
The Honor Commission is the mere vehicle which
guides observance of Honor. Its Constitution is merely
the formalized path which'the vehicle must travel in order
to preserve and guide Honor. The people in the driver's
seat must be the undergraduates, who must be able to
express their faith in Honor.
